panels.title: Number of Active Requests

panels.description: Active requests are the requests that is being actively handled by this MDS, not including the requests that are waiting in the queue. If the number of active requests is smaller than PTLRPC thread number minus two (one for incoming  request handling and the other for incoming high priority request handling), it generally means the thread number should be enough. The value shown in this graph is the minimum number during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Minimum Number of Active Requests

panels.title: Minimum Number of Active Requests

panels.description: Active requests are the requests that is being actively handled by this MDS, not including the requests that are waiting in the queue. If the number of active requests is smaller than PTLRPC thread number minus two (one for incoming  request handling and the other for incoming high priority request handling), it generally means the thread number should be enough. The value shown in this graph is the average number during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Average Number of Active Requests

panels.title: Average Number of Active Requests

panels.description: Active requests are the requests that is being actively handled by this MDS, not including the requests that are waiting in the queue. If the number of active requests is smaller than PTLRPC thread number minus two (one for incoming  request handling and the other for incoming high priority request handling), it generally means the thread number should be enough. The value shown in this graph is the maximum number during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Maximum Number of Active Requests

panels.title: Maximum Number of Active Requests
Number of Incoming Requests

panels.description: Incoming requests are the requests that waiting on preprocessing. A request is not incoming request any more when its proprocessing begins. And after preprocessing, the requests will be put into processing queue.  The value shown in this graph is the minimum number of incoming requests during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Minimum Number of Incoming Requests

panels.title: Minimum Number of Incoming Requests

panels.description: Incoming requests are the requests that waiting on preprocessing. A request is not incoming request any more when its proprocessing begins. And after preprocessing, the requests will be put into processing queue.  The value shown in this graph is the average number of incoming requests during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Average Number of Incoming Requests

panels.title: Average Number of Incoming Requests

panels.description: Incoming requests are the requests that waiting on preprocessing. A request is not incoming request any more when its proprocessing begins. And after preprocessing, the requests will be put into processing queue.  The value shown in this graph is the maximum number of incoming requests during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Maximum Number of Incoming Requests

panels.title: Maximum Number of Incoming Requests
Wait Time of Requests

panels.description: The wait time of a request is the time interval between its arrival time and the time when it starts to be handled. The value shown in this graph is the minimum wait time of the requests during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Minimum Wait Time of Requests

panels.title: Minimum Wait Time of Requests

panels.description: The wait time of a request is the time interval between its arrival time and the time when it starts to be handled. The value shown in this graph is the average wait time of the requests during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Average Wait Time of Requests

panels.title: Average Wait Time of Requests

panels.description: The wait time of a request is the time interval between its arrival time and the time when it starts to be handled. The value shown in this graph is the maximum wait time of the requests during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Maximum Wait Time of Requests

panels.title: Maximum Wait Time of Requests
Adaptive Timeout Value

panels.description: When a client sends a request, it has a timeout deadline for the reply. The timeout value of a service is an adaptive value negotiated between server and client during run-time. The value shown in this graph is the minimum timeout of the MDS service during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Minimum Adaptive Timeout Value

panels.title: Minimum Adaptive Timeout Value

panels.description: When a client sends a request, it has a timeout deadline for the reply. The timeout value of a service is an adaptive value negotiated between server and client during run-time. The value shown in this graph is the average timeout of the MDS service during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Average Adaptive Timeout Value

panels.title: Average Adaptive Timeout Value

panels.description: When a client sends a request, it has a timeout deadline for the reply. The timeout value of a service is an adaptive value negotiated between server and client during run-time. The value shown in this graph is the maximum timeout of the OST service during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Maximum Adaptive Timeout Value

panels.title: Maximum Adaptive Timeout Value
Number of Available Request Buffers

panels.description: When a request arrives, one request buffer will be used. When number of available request buffers is under low water, more buffers are needed to avoid performance bottleneck. The value shown in this graph is the minimum number during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Minimum Number of Available Request Buffers

panels.title: Minimum Number of Available Request Buffers

panels.description: When a request arrives, one request buffer will be used. When number of available request buffers is under low water, more buffers are needed to avoid performance bottleneck. The value shown in this graph is the average number during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Maximum Number of Available Request Buffers

panels.title: Maximum Number of Available Request Buffers
Handling Time of LDLM Ibits Enqueue Requests

panels.title: Minimum Adaptive Timeout Value of LDLM Callback Service

panels.description: When a client sends a request, it has a timeout deadline for the reply. The timeout value of a service is an adaptive value negotiated between server and client during run-time. The value shown in this graph is the average timeout of the service during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Average Adaptive Timeout Value of LDLM Callback Service

panels.title: Average Adaptive Timeout Value of LDLM Callback Service

panels.description: When a client sends a request, it has a timeout deadline for the reply. The timeout value of a service is an adaptive value negotiated between server and client during run-time. The value shown in this graph is the maximum timeout of the service during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Maximum Adaptive Timeout Value of LDLM Callback Service

panels.title: Maximum Adaptive Timeout Value of LDLM Callback Service
Number of Available LDLM Canceld Request Buffers

panels.description: When a request arrives, one request buffer will be used. When number of available request buffers is under low water, more buffers are needed to avoid performance bottleneck. The value shown in this graph is the minimum number during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Minimum Number of Available LDLM Callback Request Buffers

list.label: Filesystem Name
list.name: fs_name
